newsitem.title: KENYA: ATHLETICS-KENYAN PREPARATIONS HAMPERED BY HAPHAZARD SELECTIONS.
newsitem.headline: ATHLETICS-KENYAN PREPARATIONS HAMPERED BY HAPHAZARD SELECTIONS.

text.p: Kenyan preparations for the sixth world championships starting on Saturday have been hampered by the most haphazard selection and training policies for decades.
The Kenyan selectors said the first two finishers at the national trials in June would automatically win a place on the team, with a third slot based on Grand Prix circuit form.
But that policy was thrown out the window without any explanation and as a result Kenya will not field a 4x400 metres relay team nor will hurdler Erick Keter take part in Athens.
There is no place for a third 1,500 metres runner, no field athlete, no sprinters and just three women in the Kenyan team.

In addition a number of elite runners have shunned high-altitude training at the foot of Mount Kenya, the camp for all major championships since 1972, in favour of London. The Kenya Amateur Athletic Association did not pay for the London camp and could not therefore exert any control.
The association also allowed seven other athletes, including Commonwealth 800 metres champion, Patrick Konchellah, to train at home near Nairobi.
Despite the chaos, Kenyans remain optimistic about their prospects following a disappointing Olympics in Atlanta last year.
"I can assure everybody that we will give it our best performance," said Kenyan delegation leader Patrick Kiambata. "The team is in high spirits and promises gold."
Kenya's major gold prospects lie in world steeplechase champion and record holder Moses Kiptanui plus training partner and friend Daniel Komen, who will compete in the 5,000 metres.
"I want to win the steeplechase again. After that I will just hang on and try to win an Olympic gold. That is my plan for the moment," Kiptanui said.

"All is well and we are both physically and psychologically prepared for the championship. We are very sure we will have a similar success as in the world cross country championships in Italy last March," said women's 5,000 metres hopeful Lydia Cheromei.
Konchellah, younger brother of former world champion Billy Konchellah, sees himself as the only man who could come between Kenyan-born Dane Wilson Kipketer and another world championship gold.

"Kip is very strong and we all admit the fact that he is one of the best athletes of all time and also a major sensation at the games but I can assure you that we are putting up a very spirited fight for this gold," Konchellah said.
Konchellah has run the fourth fastest time of the year and last beat Kipketer in a race in Belgium in 1994.

"I have planned well for the race and all I can say is that the altitude training here has given me a great boost," said Konchellah, who returned to Kenya after finishing second to Kipketer when he equalled the world record in Stockholm this month.
